729582f-a.title: Richmond: St. Marks Place - Hyatt Street
729582f-a.text:
325 St. Marks Place, at the north-east corner of Hyatt Street, shoviug the J.C. Thompson House (1874). It later became known as the "Bella Viata" and was the home of Fred Tiedemann (1898) and, later (1907), that of Richard Agar. It was auso the property of F. Ducasse (1917). P.L. Sperr states uhat it was the home of Wm. T. Davis in 1881, when the Natural Science Association of Staten Isiand was stalrted here. Dates refer to maps on which the
Owners'names appear.
1881
Copy by km. T. Davis of photograph taken in 1881, throum P.L.Sperr

729585f-c.title: Richmond: St. Marks Place - Hyatt Street
729585f-c.text:
(1)
332 St. Marks Place, west side, at the head of Hyatt Street, showing the James Walsh residence. In 1898 the house
was owned by Mrs. E. W. Titus.
Juno 17, 1926
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The garden at the south side of the Walsh residence.
Sune 19, 1926
P. L. Sperr
(3)
The garden in the rear of the house. The
frame dwellings shown are nambers 14 to 20 Montgomery
Avenue.
June 17, 1926

728977f-a.title: Richmond: Hyatt Street - St. Marks Place
728977f-a.text:
(1)
Hyatt Street, west from Bay Street to St. Marks Place. Jn the right foreground is visible part of the Borough Hall, and in the left background is the St. George
Branch of the New York Public Library.
March 1930
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The same, at a later date. The new building, on the right, is a branch of the Staten Ialand Savings Bank, 15 Hyatt Street, occupying the site of the two dwellings seen directly to the left of the Borough Bball in view 1.
May 26, 1937
P. L. Sperr

729584f-a.text:
332 St. Marks Place, west side, at the head
of Hyatt Street, showing the former James Walsh house after taxpayers have been erected in front of it. On the right
is the Brighton Heights Reformed Church.
June 13, 1937
